destination.label: Toulouse
destination.title: Toulouse: the pink city of a thousand flavours

content.intro:
Between the Atlantic and the Mediterranean, the heart of the South-west beats in Toulouse.

A perfect combination of lifestyle and history, surrounded by magnificent scenery, Toulouse is genuinely charming with its southern 'midi' accent. The former capital of the Languedoc, today the pearl of the Occitanie region, Toulouse has shone in France for a very long time. The voice of history still rings out on every street corner: the 'pink city', thus named because of the colour of the specific clay brick of the region, displays the struggles of history and time.
The golden age of the city, between the 12th and 15th centuries, gave it its finest convents, like the Cordeliers and the Jacobins. Lovers of art and architecture will enjoy strolling around the Place du Capitole, built according to the classical canons of the 17th century, and through the streets of this city of shimmering colours.
The character of Toulouse also comes from its emblems, which have made it famous throughout France. Its rugby team, Stade Toulousain, has conquered the world of rugby, and its gastronomy is hearty and delicious. For Epicureans, Toulousain cassoulet remains a highlight of every holiday. Try its local variations, from Toulouse, Castelnaudary or Carcassonne. In addition, its vineyards produce some of the best under-rated treasures of France.
From the Garonne to the Mediterranean, the Canal du Midi, an exceptional work of 17th-century engineering, offers the charms, surprises and leisurely pace of the inland waterways. Finally, about an hour from Toulouse near the regional Causses du Quercy park, you will have the opportunity to spend a night in the trees, close to the stars. Between gastronomic delights, historical strolls, and excursions to the surrounding countryside, enjoying the good life in Toulouse is assured.

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Toulouse

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Toulouse

content.title: Merville Maze, a cultural escape game

introduction.small: Visitors of all ages will love the myriad of puzzles and thrilling challenges to solve at Melville Castle.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Merville Maze, a cultural escape game

paragraphs.text:
Around 20km from Toulouse, Merville Castle - a superb pink brick building dating back to the early 18th century - towers over the surrounding area. However interesting the building may be, the main attraction is out in the gardens, where pathways lined with vast box hedges cover almost six kilometres of the grounds. Slip inside these green passageways and lose yourself in the biggest boxwood maze in Europe…

In this veritable outdoor escape game, walkers are asked to solve mysteries and complete challenges as they follow one of two routes. The first is “Enigma”, which is themed around inventions and key figures in the history of science like Marie Curie, Leonardo da Vinci, Galileo and even Bill Gates. Here, you will need to solve puzzles to get past obstacles, water doors and gates, and crack the code to escape the maze.

The other route is “Dédale”, which will take you on a wonderful wander peppered with historical anecdotes about the castle and grounds. Using a combination of a mobile app downloaded on your smartphone and nine interactive terminals along the route, you will get to travel through 250 years of the estate's history, from when it was built by the Marquis de Chalvet and Seneschal of Toulouse until it was handed down to the Marquis de Beaumont du Repaire, the ancestor of the current owners.

During one unforgettable afternoon, the whole family can go back in time and discover the many different histories to this unique place.

Labyrinthe et château de Merville
1175 chemin de Grande Borde
31330 Merville

+33 (0)5 61 85 32 34

https://www.labyrinthedemerville.com/?page_id=289&lang=en

content.title: On a culinary journey at Nomades

introduction.small: Come and share your love of journeying in the very heart of Toulouse, on a sun-drenched terrace facing the Saint-Étienne cathedral.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: On a culinary journey at Nomades

paragraphs.text:
The lovely red front is a perfect match for the city's brick buildings. Entering Nomades in the historic centre of Toulouse is a little bit like reconnecting with a spirit of exploration and liberty left aside for too long in daily life. Decoration is stripped-down and strikes a balance in which the essential is enough.

For your gustatory enjoyment, the owners Arnaud, Sylvain and Valentin offer you a tasty menu full of flavours inspired by their own experiences across the world, but using only fresh, local and seasonal products. Here, these three travelling enthusiasts revisit the recipes of chef and globetrotter Patrick Brandao. Dishes are authentic and straightforward, as every mouthful of your beef bourguignon tacos with a wine and mustard sauce, or pollock ceviche with sweet potatoes, grilled corn, coconut and wasabi foam, and prickly pear and pomegranate dressing will attest. For curious patrons who welcome some guidance, a unique menu is served every night. You got it right, the atmosphere is definitely special. So be ready to embark on a culinary journey at the table and marvel, as a bonus, at the wonderful view over the Saint-Étienne cathedral..

Nomades
1 rue Riguepels
31000 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 32 59 67 53

https://www.facebook.com/nomades.restaurant/

Menu: around 27 EUR

content.title: Grand cru wines in self-service at 5 Wine Bar

introduction.small: Three times wine bar world champion, 5 Wine Bar stands out from all others in Toulouse with its Grand cru self-service concept.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grand cru wines in self-service at 5 Wine Bar

paragraphs.text:
It is the pride and joy of Toulouse and even the entire region. Crowned best wine bar in the world on multiple occasions by the major British magazine The World of Fine Wine, 5 Wine Bar is the only establishment of its kind to have been awarded three years in a row. With over 4,000 references, including 500 by the glass, all wine-producing regions on the globe are present, even though the Toulouse bar remains a strong proponent of local wines, offering various selections by the glass at a low price (to be enjoyed in moderation of course).

Far removed from traditional wine bars, the success of 5 Wine Bar largely holds due to its Grand cru self-service concept. Wine and champagne lovers can fill their glasses directly, depending on their thirst (1.5cl, 4.5cl or 10cl). In the lobby, you simply need to insert a card as if you were at an ATM, and then serve yourself. Rest assured, you are in good hands as seasoned sommeliers are available to guide your choice. Kitchen-side, wines can be accompanied by a few tapas also from small local producers.

5 Wine Bar
5 rue de la Bourse
31000 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 61 38 44 51

https://www.n5winebar.com/fr/

Menu: glass from 3 EUR

content.title: Bistroquet à la une, three-in-one

introduction.small: In Toulouse's Wilson district, Bistroquet à la une is at once bistro, canteen-like restaurant and tapas bar. Pick the one(s) you like!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bistroquet à la une, three-in-one

paragraphs.text:
Behind Wilson square, lunch time strikes two very different approaches at Bistroquet à la une. On one side, the bistro with its authentic and market-based cuisine displayed on the slate. On the other, the canteen and its lovely dishes in a small plate (those XS-type dishes that come one after the other) allowing your party to share (or not, depending on everyone's hunger) various flavours in one meal.

Everything here is made with fresh ingredients, and recipes change according to the seasons. Baked camembert, shredded duck with chimichurri, foie gras mi-cuit with toast… it makes it so hard to choose! Unless you opt for one of their delicious prime ribs, aged for a minimum of 35 days. And on Sundays, it is brunch time at the canteen!

These two very distinctive styles come together at Bistroquet à la une, and they even blend at night into a welcoming and friendly tapas bar.

Bistroquet à la une
10 rue Labeda
31000 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 34 30 55 71

https://www.bistroquetalaune.com/

Menu: around 21 EUR

content.title: Mama Shelter on Toulouse time

introduction.small: Mama Shelter has settled into a new location in the heart of Toulouse near the Pierre Goudouli garden, and is paying tribute to the pink city at every opportunity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mama Shelter on Toulouse time

paragraphs.text:
With Mama Shelter's distinctive candy pink and raspberry frontage, you would be hard-pressed not to notice the stylish, trendy hotel chain's new home in Toulouse. Away from the hustle and bustle of the city centre, but still just a ten-minute walk to the Capitole, the hotel has become part of the fabric of local life. Look up as you step inside to see a work of art by Beni Lloyds bright against the black chalkboard ceiling of its bar and restaurant. It pays homage to life in Toulouse, and there is plenty of fun to be had spotting words in Occitan, references to the Garonne, and lyrics from songs by Claude Nougaro. The building itself is one of the former cinemas so typical of the area, and it too has been celebrated by its new occupant with CinéMama, a private space reserved for hotel and restaurant guests. As one last tribute to Toulouse, there is the rooftop bar: head up at sunset and you will find not only a pizza oven and cart filled with homemade ice creams and sorbets, but also unrivalled views of the pink city ablaze in the day's last rays of sunshine.

Mama Shelter Toulouse
54-56 boulevard Lazare Carnot
31000 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 31 50 50 05

https://mamashelter.com/toulouse/

Rooms: from 79 EUR

content.title: Hôtel des Beaux Arts, character and eclecticism

introduction.small: In Toulouse, this boutique hotel offers rooms with distinct universes, but also unobstructed views over the Garonne River and the city's historic centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel des Beaux Arts, character and eclecticism

paragraphs.text:
It would be hard to find a better location in Toulouse: two steps away from the Pont-Neuf bridge in the Carmes neighbourhood, the Hôtel des Beaux Arts is housed in an 18th-century building, which is also a listed monument. The 18 pleasant rooms offer picture-postcard views of either the Garonne River or the city's historic centre. Each is practically a work of art in itself, right down to the layout, with a unique theme to every one: "Icons", elegant in its sobriety, displays black and white portraits of David Bowie, Serge Gainsbourg and Catherine Deneuve. The "Maye" room was named after a street artist from Montpellier and, as the name suggests, "Tribute to Mondrian" bears the mark of famous early 20th-century Dutch painter and pioneer of Abstract art Piet Mondrian. Often decorated by upcoming artists, the rooms display various original art pieces. Bargain-hunt from your bed - who knows, you may make an impulse buy!

Hôtel des Beaux Arts
1 place du Pont-Neuf
31000 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 34 45 42 42

https://www.hoteldesbeauxarts.com/en

Rooms: from 79 EUR

content.title: Art unfolds at Les Abattoirs in Toulouse

introduction.small: Discover Les Abattoirs, an original art museum in the heart of a unique place.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Art unfolds at Les Abattoirs in Toulouse

paragraphs.text:
district, the cultural site gathers three structures in one place: the modern art museum, centre for contemporary art, and the region's public collection of contemporary art. Opened in 2000, Les Abattoirs houses works of 20th-century artists all through today. The collection has been gradually enriched and expanded by donations from private collections (notably Anthony and Celia Denney), as well as Centre Pompidou.
Since 2013, the museum offers a multidisciplinary programme, with concerts, talks, performances and screenings, making Les Abattoirs a cultural spot you cannot miss during your stay in the Pink City.
Admire works by renowned artists such as Marcel Duchamp, Robert Mapplethorpe, Andy Warhol, André Jacquemin, Niki de Saint-Phalle and Miró. After your visit, take a stroll in the Raymond VI Garden that surrounds the museum.

Les Abattoirs
76 allées Charles-de-Fitte
31300 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 34 51 10 60

https://www.lesabattoirs.org/en

content.title: La Voile Blanche, heading to the trendy Toulouse address

introduction.small: At the gates of Toulouse, Sesquières Park is home to La Voile Blanche, a complex that includes a restaurant, club and beach, on the shores of a lake.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Voile Blanche, heading to the trendy Toulouse address

paragraphs.text:
La Voile Blanche is the address where you should spend your evenings to satisfy your desire to go out. In a party atmosphere around the pool, start off with dinner at the La Cantine 26 restaurant. The decor is very modern, with black leather benches and dark tones on the walls. Choose an assortment of tapas to share - deep-fried calamari with house-made aioli, sweet potato churros, or prawns wrapped in potato strings with a Thai sauce- or indulge in something from the excellent menu: the octopus platter served with ratatouille and chorizo, and the beef carpaccio with pesto and pine nuts are both wonderful choices. Carry on with an impressive grilled duck breast served in cep mushroom cream and with homemade fries, or the grilled king prawns in garlic and herbs with smashed potatoes. For dessert, do not miss the strawberry, mint and basil gazpacho with vanilla ice cream, or the raspberry and pistachio Charlotte Russe cake.

Events are regularly organised, such as Latin and reggae parties, pool parties, etc. You will certainly have a great time at La Voile Blanche, in a relaxed and warm atmosphere.

La Voile Blanche
Parc de Sesquières
26 allée des Foulques
31200 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 62 27 07 45

https://www.lavoile-blanche.fr

Menu: from 31 EUR

content.title: Guided tour of Carcassonne and surroundings from Toulouse

introduction.small: Discover the most beautiful spots of Carcassonne and its millennia of history with an expert guide!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Guided tour of Carcassonne and surroundings from Toulouse

paragraphs.text:
Carcassonne, known both for its various UNESCO World Heritage sites and famous music festival is the perfect place for all medieval remain lovers. Discover one of Europe's biggest fortified city of Middle Ages, offering an ideal setting for peaceful tours and getaways. 2,500 years of history, three kilometres of fortress walls scattered with 52 towers from which to look over the Pyrenees mountain chain, a 19th-century castle restored by architect Viollet-le-Duc, as well as an exceptional basilica… Immerse yourself in its charming streets to admire the city's various period buildings and impressive ramparts, or visit its gorgeous museums, churches and gardens.
Carcassonne mixes medieval history and modern life to make you transcend the ages for a half a day.
So, do not hesitate anymore and conquer this fortress together with your guide!

Carcassonne Tourist Information Centre
28 rue de Verdun
11890 Carcassonne

+33 (0)4 68 10 24 30

https://www.tourism-carcassonne.co.uk/

content.title: Les Bains Douches: aesthetic harmony

introduction.small: All the charm of an Art Deco hotel, in a lively neighbourhood containing the former Halle aux Grains, now home to Toulouse's Capitole National Orchestra.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Bains Douches: aesthetic harmony

paragraphs.text:
The facade of the hotel is alone worth the visit: in pure Art Deco style, the immense mosaic that covers the corner building is actually a work of art.

In a white stone and metal frame, the building will surprise you with its charm. The interior will not disappoint you either, as this former bathhouse has been rehabilitated with taste, harmoniously combining design with a warm atmosphere. The rooms, in shades of taupe and clad in glass, bring to your nights a revisited 1930s spirit. It is a one-of-a-kind address with a trendy and modern atmosphere.

As in many boutique hotels, examples of the very original Italian furniture are for sale. For music lovers, the nearby Halle aux Grains is the home to Toulouse's Capitole National Orchestra and a focus of Toulouse's musical scene. Atmosphere guaranteed!

Les Bains Douches
4, rue du Pont Guilheméry
31000 Toulouse
+33 (0)5 62 72 52 52

www.hotel-bainsdouches.com

Rooms: from 110 EUR

content.title: Following the story of woad

introduction.small: Known worldwide, the famous blue dye that reached its heyday in the Renaissance was born on the banks of the Garonne.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Following the story of woad

paragraphs.text:
Unlike the pink colours of the city, this characteristic blue dye issues from a plant called isatis tinctoria, and more commonly known as woad. This plant used in the maceration of the dye was renowned in the Toulouse region in the Renaissance.

The harvest of the leaves, and the elaboration of the dye result in balls or shells called cocagnes, from which the dye is extracted. This is the origin of the expression 'Land of Cockaigne', which came to mean 'land of plenty'. The Toulouse traders became considerably richer as blue became increasingly fashionable in the 15th century. So today you can enjoy the magnificent mansions built in the city at that time, and which now appear with their beautiful… pink facades.

Push open the door of La Fleurée de Pastel, a small boutique with old-world charm that features dyed creations based on natural colours, such as silks or cottons with deep and authentic blues, but also beautiful soaps.

La Fleurée de Pastel
20, rue de la Bourse
31000 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 61 12 05 94

http://lafleureedepastel.fr/

content.title: Le Bibent: an emblematic Toulouse restaurant

introduction.small: This Toulouse institution is a great place to enjoy some classic Toulouse cuisine, complete with views of the Capitol.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Bibent: an emblematic Toulouse restaurant

paragraphs.text:
Do not hesitate to push open the door of this bright and welcoming Art Deco bistro, which opened for the first time in the late 19thcentury. Today, Yann Ghazal manages this famous Toulouse landmark, open seven days a week. The interior is a whirl of panelling, stucco mouldings, mosaics, and other Baroque follies that give the restaurant the dimensions of an old brasserie, but with a true bistro style.

In the kitchen, the classics revisited by the chef will not disappoint: a ginger-spiced oyster, bass and salmon tartare, bream tartare, beef and marrow-stuffed potatoes, guinea fowl supreme with fresh cheese, garlic and herbs, and Joël Robuchon's signature potato purée.. To celebrate the end of a delicious meal, go for the strawberries in vanilla oil, whipped fresh cream and rhubarb sorbet, or the raspberry, pistachio and orange blossom tart.
A menu drawn between the old and the new, and a succession of delights and pleasures. A cheerful experience, full of light.

Le Bibent
5 place du Capitole
31000 Toulouse

+33 (0)6 48 71 73 65

https://lebibent.com

Menu: around 50 EUR

content.title: Grand Hôtel de l'Opéra: classic elegance

introduction.small: A bright and cosy hotel for a lovely stay in the pink city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grand Hôtel de l'Opéra: classic elegance

paragraphs.text:
For those seeking a cosy and welcoming atmosphere above all, this wonderfully located hotel is the perfect setting. This former 17th-century convent turned four-star hotel will plunge you in its high-end and subdued environment. The lobby opens onto a salon with a large glass roof that floods light on to the (opera, of course) red velvet sofas and dark wood furniture.

Flowery wallpaper and weathered club armchairs offer a sumptuous welcome where comfort rhymes with pleasure. Each room is carefully decorated with marble and mahogany, beautiful fabrics, and fine furniture.

Both indoor and outdoor, the restaurant, located in the hotel's courtyard, will delight foodies with its gastronomic and modern cuisine. For relaxation, the Terre de Jade wellness area offers hot stone massages that are simply divine, as well as sophrology and reiki sessions, holistic techniques that drive you to sheer serenity.

Grand Hôtel de l'Opéra
1 place du Capitole
31000 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 61 21 82 66

https://www.grand-hotel-opera.com/en/

Rooms: from 119 EUR

content.title: La Cour des Consuls: an exceptional showcase

introduction.small: Located in the heart of the city, this 17th-century mansion is now a five-star hotel of exemplary comfort.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Cour des Consuls: an exceptional showcase

paragraphs.text:
Renovated with impeccable taste following the rules of art, La Cour des Consuls in the Carmes neighbourhood (the historic centre of Toulouse) will elicit raves from those seeking luxury and comfort. At once cosy and contemporary, the five-star hotel displays beautiful colours in harmony with the identity of the place.

The proof is in the rooms, as each one offers a special, impeccable atmosphere, with modern wooden floors, historic coving and warm colours for one, and contemporary grey carpet and curtains for another. Nothing is left to chance here.

The interior terrace and the Graine de Pastel spa, offering Southwest-made natural cosmetics, will make your stay a perfect stopover for discovering the Pink City. Le Cénacle, the prestigious guest table, is open to a majestic fireplace, while the intimate English bar does nothing to detract from your enjoyment…

La Cour des Consuls Hotel & Spa
46 rue des Couteliers
31000 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 67 16 19 99

https://www.cite-hotels.com/en/etablissements/hotel-cour-des-consuls.html

Rooms: from 212 EUR

content.title: Le Grand Balcon: a timeless address

introduction.small: Located 30 m from the Place du Capitole, the Grand Balcon is an ideal spot for those who want to be at the emblematic heart of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Grand Balcon: a timeless address

paragraphs.text:
The 1930s style of the establishment gives it a special charm, while its red brick facade and bright lobby make it a renowned landmark in the city.

The resolutely modern decor has been designed with comfort in mind. Soothing grey dominates in standard rooms, while blue-and-white tones make each superior room a perfect refuge. The view of the pink city from the suites, meanwhile, is sure to delight all.

Thanks to Isabelle Klein, a local antique dealer, the Saint-Exupéry suite recalls the beginnings of airmail and the times of this iconic hero of French history in an atmosphere worthy of a film set. To stay in this beautiful suite and experience a journey through time via an original and unique décor, ask for room 32, where Saint-Exupéry, the aviator and author of The Little Prince, actually slept. It is now listed as a place of remembrance by Bâtiments de France.

Le Grand Balcon
8-10 rue Romiguières
31000 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 34 25 44 09

https://grandbalconhotel.com

Rooms: from 109 EUR

content.title: The Chasselas de Moissac grape: a fruit of great character

introduction.small: You can find this delicious white grape with a thousand virtues just outside of Toulouse.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Chasselas de Moissac grape: a fruit of great character

paragraphs.text:
Enjoy a rustic interlude in Moissac about 50 kilometres from Toulouse, a lovely town surrounded by orchards and fragrant vineyards.

The climate of the valley allows the culture of many fruits, including that of the famous Chasselas de Moissac grape, which has made the reputation of the city. Come taste it in its myriad forms and discover its highly detoxifying properties. Its consumption helps to purify the body and to rapidly regenerate cells, so the Chasselas course of treatment is a classic in the region. During your time in the medieval city, you can also visit the Saint-Pierre Abbey and adjoining cloisters, masterpieces of Roman art that have been listed as UNESCO World Heritage sites.

While you are there, book a table at M. 1474, the restaurant at the Le Moulin de Moissac hotel, for a gourmet fine-dining experience. The splendid views of the surrounding countryside and the bucolic banks of the Tarn are an additional attraction.

Le Moulin de Moissac
1 promenade Sancert
82200 Moissac
+33 (0)5 63 32 88 88
https://www.lemoulindemoissac.com

Abbaye Saint-Pierre de Moissac
6 place Durand de Bredon
82200 Moissac
+33 (0)5 63 04 01 85
http://www.abbayemoissac.com/en

content.title: Toulouse gastronomy: a discovery in good taste

introduction.small: The discovery of gourmet specialities from the south-west is a necessity in Toulouse.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Toulouse gastronomy: a discovery in good taste

paragraphs.text:
You cannot stay in Toulouse without tasting the iconic cassoulet, a typical dish of the region, which has been the source of several quarrels between the cities of Toulouse, Carcassonne, and Castelnaudary, who all claim its invention.

It is a dish comprised of the white beans of Tarbes and of Toulouse sausage, and is eaten throughout the year in the pink city. The Maison Garcia has held the reputation as the city's best butcher for a long time and is a must visit on your gourmet walk. You will find, of course, the Toulouse sausage, but also other excellent meat sausages. To end on a sweet note, discover the local apple crisp, a puff pastry made with Armagnac-scented fruit. The Sandyan pastry shop is apt to assuage all your cravings for sweets.

Finish with a taste of violets, another Toulouse speciality, by trying a delicious sorbet made with the aromas of the little flower that once made the fame of the city at Philippe Faur, the ice cream maker you will find inside Le Florida café.

Maison Garcia
Marché Victor Hugo
Place Victor Hugo
31000 Toulouse
+33 (0)5 61 23 10 62
https://www.maison-garcia.fr

Pâtisserie Sandyan
54 bis rue d'Alsace-Lorraine
31000 Toulouse
+33 (0)5 61 21 45 64
https://sandyan.fr

Glacier Philippe Faur
Le Florida
12 place du Capitole
31000 Toulouse
+33 (0)5 61 23 94 61
https://www.philippefaur.com

content.title: Stade Toulousain, a rugby institution

introduction.small: Toulouse aspires to be the capital of French rugby, a sport played in an atmosphere not to be missed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stade Toulousain, a rugby institution

paragraphs.text:
The legendary Toulouse team, Stade Toulousain, has enabled the city to acquire worldwide fame in sports. The greatest rugby players in the world come to live in the pink city to practice this legendary game. Toulouse's game philosophy is well-known worldwide, all the way to the shores of New Zealand: home to the All Blacks.

Rugby arrived in the region in the 19th century and was first played in the city's universities. The traditional team colours are red and black, in memory of the former capitouls, or sheriffs, who were municipal councillors.

During your stay in Toulouse, and depending on the season, be sure to attend a match at the stadium to watch this legendary team play. Take advantage of the 'third half' and head to the Rouge et Noir, the official supporters' bar with unique decoration that pays tribute to the local club. Spending some time with the friendly fans of this iconic sport is guaranteed to be a welcoming experience - supercharged!

Stade toulousain - Ernest-Wallon
114 rue des Troènes
31200 Toulouse
https://www.stadetoulousain.fr/accueil

Le Rouge et Noir
3 rue du pont Saint-Pierre
31300 Toulouse
https://www.facebook.com/pages/Le-Rouge-Et-Noir/319039751950115

content.title: Toulouse by water

introduction.small: Embark on an unusual tour of the city via its waterways.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Toulouse by water

paragraphs.text:
Toulouse is located on the banks of the Garonne and the Canal du Midi, with a range of cruises to choose from for a tranquil few hours' sailing through the Pink City.

This is a delightful experience, especially in summer, allowing you to admire the monuments and bridges of the city from another perspective. The barge cruises take you where you choose, on the Garonne around central Toulouse, or the Canal du Midi and the Canal de Brienne outside the city. For those who wish, small boats may be rented for limited use.

The Canal du Midi is a marvel of ingenuity and a complete change of scene with the romance of its green banks. Strolling under the majestic tall trees that border the canal is also not to be missed. Built in the 17th century, the canal connects the Garonne River to the Mediterranean and thus allows a river link from the Atlantic to the Mediterranean.

Canal du Midi
https://www.canal-du-midi.org/en/

content.title: Spend a night in the trees

introduction.small: Climb into one of these pretty treetop cabins for a night in the heart of nature.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Spend a night in the trees

paragraphs.text:
What could be more romantic than to spend the night on a treetop? In the middle of the Quercy Valley, less than an hour from Toulouse, the Domaine de la Male welcomes you for an unforgettable stay in one of its cabins, which have been built on stilts high among the trees. Rest assured your ecological fibre will remain unscathed: not a single nail has been used amid this six-hectare forest.

In these original and romantic surroundings, you will get to enjoy stunning views of the landscape around you, as well as outstanding comfort. The rooms will charm you with their harmonies of light-coloured wood, while the Jacuzzi on the cabin's terrace provides total relaxation.

A gourmet basket will be delivered by pulley for your dinner, should you so wish, allowing you to live a treetop dream amid the oaks. The domain can also enlighten those who wish to learn more about the riches of nature in the south-west.

Domaine de la Male
Lieu-dit La Male
82800 Puygaillard-de-Quercy

+33 (0)6 71 60 66 03

https://www.domainedelamale.fr

Rooms: from 130 EUR

content.title: The mansions of Toulouse: architectural gems

introduction.small: Stroll the streets of Toulouse and discover the Pink City's stunning mansions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The mansions of Toulouse: architectural gems

paragraphs.text:
Toulouse's emblematic hôtels particuliers (mansions), previously owned by the nobility or rich pastel merchants, may be visited during your walks in the city centre.

The famous Hôtel d'Assézat opens its doors not far from the Place Esquirol. This splendid house in a typical Renaissance style was built by the most sought-after architect of the 16th century, Nicolas Bachelier. While admiring the mansion's inner courtyard, you might note that it is almost a replica of the Cour Carrée of the Louvre. The Bemberg Foundation, now a museum that brings together an impressive collection of paintings, may also be visited. Carrying on, Antoine Dumay, a doctor renowned for having treated Queen Margot - the first wife of King Henry IV - built the Dumay Mansion in the 16th century.

Our next stop is the Hôtel Jean de Bagis, a magnificent example of the Toulouse Renaissance. Built for a wealthy chairman of the parliament of Toulouse, this mansion has the nickname of 'the stone mansion' because its facade is one of the few examples of stone (not brick) construction in the city.

Fondation Bemberg - Hôtel d'Assézat
Place d'Assézat
31000 Toulouse
+33 (0)5 61 12 06 89
https://www.fondation-bemberg.fr/fr/home.html

Hôtel Dumay - Musée du vieux Toulouse
7 rue du May
31000 Toulouse
+33 (0)5 62 27 11 50
https://toulousainsdetoulouse.fr/lassociation

Hôtel Jean de Bagis
(also known as "hôtel de Clary" and "hôtel de pierre")
25 rue de la Dalbade
31000 Toulouse
https://monumentum.fr/hotel-pierre-dit-aussi-hotel-jean-bagis-pa00094563.html

content.title: Michel Sarran: the gastronomic exception

introduction.small: Enjoy top-flight cuisine celebrating both the land and sea in warm, welcoming surroundings.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Michel Sarran: the gastronomic exception

paragraphs.text:
Indulge yourself by booking a table with this extraordinary chef, who arrived in Toulouse in 1995 and is very much leaving his mark on the city. At Michel Sarran, dining is not taken lightly. 'We are merchants of pleasure', announces the Michelin-starred chef proudly.
Everything breathes the art of living and generosity in this restaurant, with its tasteful and warm decoration. In the kitchen, the spirit of 'home' dominates the dishes: recipes combine modernity and traditions, a remarkable union that will surprise your taste buds.

Start with a blanquette of frogs legs with basil served on a flaky mushroom and chorizo galette, followed by bass in a seaweed and dashi broth with three-cornered brown shrimp and preserved rhubarb ravioli if you are a fan of fish. Alternatively, there is the warm duck foie gras soup with Belon oyster, and the Mont Royal pigeon served with fennel, purple artichokes and black garlic, a parsley crumb and Kalamata olive jus.

If you have a sweet tooth, the desserts make the aromas sing: a chocolate disc with Gers walnuts on a dacquoise with cocoa sorbet and walnut oil snow, a croustade filled with apples flambeed in Armagnac and a Baked Alaska with orange liqueur, or a fresh peach poached in red wine with tarragon sorbet will make your mouth water: prepare for pleasure that you will not be able to resist.

Michel Sarran Restaurant
21 boulevard Armand Duportal
31000 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 61 12 32 32

https://www.michel-sarran.com/en/

Menu: around 60 EUR

content.title: Discovering Toulouse's Capitole

introduction.small: Dive into the history of the pink city by visiting the Capitol.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discovering Toulouse's Capitole

paragraphs.text:
The Capitol, the city's main square, is a jewel of neoclassical art of the 17th century, with its pink bricks and majestic facades.

It has been the emblem of the city since it was built more than eight centuries ago, and remains the seat of municipal power: the arts are also represented by a theatre. Its construction was decided in the very heyday of the city in the 12th century, but you can also admire the facades dating from the 17th. Look down when in the middle of the 12,000-sqm square and observe the beautiful Languedoc cross, the emblem of the city and the work of the artist Raymond Moretti.

Inside the theatre, there is a monumental staircase offering access to the floors, decorated with impressive frescoes depicting the history of the city. The city hall offers a tourist train for discovering the city's monuments in another light, including the Capitol.

Place du Capitole
31000 Toulouse

https://www.toulouse-visit.com/le-capitole-hotel-de-ville/toulouse/pcumid031fs000a3

content.title: Albi: the beautiful rival

introduction.small: Not far from Toulouse is Albi, a city that boasts surprising colours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Albi: the beautiful rival

paragraphs.text:
Once you arrive in Albi, around an hour's drive from Toulouse, the first thing that will impress you is the immense red-brick Saint Cecilia Cathedral: the only church built on this scale with this material in the world. Constructed in the 13th century, its 135m give it the appearance of a fortified castle (which it was originally).

Just next door, you can push open the heavy doors of the Berbie Palace, the dashingly beautiful former Episcopal Palace, which now houses the Toulouse-Lautrec Museum. Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, born in Albi, was the direct descendant of the Counts of Toulouse and was raised here. Aristocratic, whimsical, and small in stature due to a genetic disease, the painter made this last quality an asset. After his death (at age 37), his family bequeathed many paintings to his hometown, including his various portraits of artist Yvette Guilbert.

While you are here, we suggest you try the delicious recipes of L'Épicurien, one of Albi's finest tables, which features its own organic bread, fresh seasonal ingredients, and a savvy, well-conceived menu.

Musée Toulouse-Lautrec
Palais de la Berbie
Place Sainte-Cécile
81000 Albi
+33 (0)5 63 49 48 70
https://musee-toulouse-lautrec.com/en

L'Epicurien
42 place Jean-Jaurès
81000 Albi
+33 (0)5 63 53 10 70
https://www.restaurantlepicurien.com/

content.title: Le Saint-Sernin, a charming nest

introduction.small: Across from the splendid basilica of Saint-Sernin, this intimate and personalised hotel assures a restful stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Saint-Sernin, a charming nest

paragraphs.text:
If your prime concern is calm and tranquillity, this small hotel renovated on multiple counts since it opened in 1948 and with only 17 rooms is the perfect companion.

The carefully designed, classic decor referencing the rich artistic Occitan culture of Medieval times in muted tones adorns this establishment, which is situated in the city centre. An ideal location, only a stone's throw from lively areas filled with bars and restaurants by the Place du Capitole, that remains calm at night, for your sleeping enjoyment. All rooms are customised and some even offer great views of the 11th-century basilica of Saint-Sernin.

In summer, the greenery that is so abundant outside your bedroom window is a delight. The small seating area on the ground floor is a fine spot to quietly sit and enjoy this friendly place, where attentive service seems to be the trademark.

Le Saint-Sernin
2 rue Saint-Bernard
31000 Toulouse

+33 (0)5 61 21 73 08

https://www.hotelstsernin.com/en/

Rooms: from 80 EUR

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Toulouse
content.introduction: Toulouse enjoys a temperate climate with oceanic and Mediterranean influences. Summers (June to September) are dry and hot, while winters (December to March) are relatively mild.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in France is the Euro (EUR).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Toulouse-Blagnac Airport
airports.description:
The Toulouse-Blagnac Airport is located in the town of Blagnac, about eight kilometres (five miles) northwest of Toulouse.
  • One terminal, with four halls: A, B, C and D

Getting from the airport to Toulouse and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the A621 motorway. Travel time is about 15 minutes to the city centre.
    • Various parking facilities are available (drop-off area, short and long-term):
      • Express Drop-Off, one-minute walk: first ten minutes are free, then EUR 1.60 for 11-15 minutes and EUR 3.10 for 16-30 minutes. After 30 minutes, parking costs EUR 1.50 per extra 5 minutes.
      • Express Parking (P0), two-minute walk: first ten minutes are free, then EUR 1.70 for 11-15 minutes, EUR 2.10 for 16-30 minutes, EUR 3.30 for 31-45 minutes and EUR 4.20 for 46 minutes-1 hour.
      • Proxi Parking (P1, P2 and P3), between two and seven minutes' walk: EUR 20.20 for 24 hours, EUR 40.40 for 2 days.
      • Eco Parking (P5 and P6), accessed via a free shuttle that runs every ten minutes from 4 a.m. to 1 a.m.: EUR 17.10 for 24 hours, EUR 31.90 for two days, EUR 41.90 for three days, and EUR 57.80 for seven days. For a complete pricing list, please visit www.toulouse.aeroport.fr/en/passengers/to-and-from/car-park.
    • Several car rental companies have counters at halls C and D.
  • By bus
    • Shuttle buses depart every 20 minutes from a stop outside exit C2 on the arrivals level. Travel time is 20 to 45 minutes. The buses run from 5:05 a.m. to 21:40 a.m. in the direction of the Toulouse bus station, and from 5:40 a.m. to 12:10 a.m. towards the airport. The fare is EUR 8.00 per trip.
    • Bus line 30 serves the MEETT (Toulouse Exhibition & Convention Centre) - EUR 1.70 per ride.
    • Bus line 88 operated by the conseil général de la Haute-Garonne serves the city of Toulouse and surrounding communities (EUR 2.20 per ride).
  • By taxi
    • Taxi ranks are located outside the arrivals area, between exits B3 and C1. You may call ahead to make a reservation, +33 (0)5 61 30 02 54.
    • The fare to central Toulouse is approximately EUR 25.
  • By tram
    • The new T2 line connects the airport with the city centre, with trams running every 9 to 15 minutes. The first departure from the city centre (Arènes) is at 5:35 a.m. and the last at 11:30 p.m. Travel time is between 20 and 30 minutes depending on the destination and the fare is EUR 1.70 each way.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, valet parking, and free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +33 (0)825 380 000
  • Website: www.toulouse.aeroport.fr/en

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Toulouse
transportation.description: Toulouse's public transport system is one of the best and most efficient in France. The city's buses and its metro offer excellent coverage and are both easy to use and convenient. Exploring the city centre on foot or by bicycle is also an excellent option, particularly given that there are many road restrictions in place around the Place du Capitole: it is worth avoiding using your car to get around.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Toulouse, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organize your stay.

information.title: Toulouse Tourist Office
information.description:
Offers practical information (sightseeing, tours, heritage sites and cultural institutions, nights out on the town, etc.) and publications for tourists on the city of Toulouse and its region.

  • Address: Donjon du Capitole, square Charles de Gaulle, 31000 Toulouse
  • Opening hours: Monday to Saturday from 9:30 a.m. to 7:00 p.m., Sunday and holidays from 10:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m.
  • Telephone: +33 (0)5 17 42 31 31
  • Website: https://www.toulouse-visit.com/

information.title: French Travel Guide
information.description:
The official tourism website of France has plenty of information available on Toulouse.

  • Website: http://www.atout-france.fr/content/covid-19-1

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Toulouse counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to France. For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr/
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)

call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description: There are no specific food safety risks. French government authorities promote good hygiene practices and put in place strengthened control procedures for sites especially frequented by tourists during the summer months.

information.title: Water
information.description: Tap water is safe to drink in Toulouse.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic French phrases that will make your stay in Toulouse a little easier:
phrases: I don't understand: Je ne comprends pas
What time is it?: Quelle heure est-il ?
How much is (…)?: Quel est le prix de (…) ?
Where can I find (…)?: Où puis-je trouver (…) ?
Where can I buy (…)?: Où puis-je acheter (…) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Toulouse
localCalendar.description:
There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Toulouse each year.
The main ones are listed below.

events.title: March or April: Easter Monday (national holiday)
May 1 : Labour Day (national holiday)
events.description: On the first of May, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. On this day, sellers can be found on almost every corner!

events.title: May 8: Victory Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the Allied victory in Europe that ended World War II on this day in 1945. Various ceremonies are held around town.

events.title: June 21: Fête de la Musique (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Also celebrated internationally as World Music Day, for this festival many free concerts featuring all types of music are held in the streets and at various venues across Toulouse.

events.title: July 14: Bastille Day (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday celebrates the storming of the Bastille prison in 1789, the key event marking the beginning of the French Revolution. It plays as a symbol of the end of the privileges enjoyed by the clergy and the aristocracy. In Toulouse, evening festivities include a concert at Prairie des Filtres and fireworks set off from barges floating on the Garonne.

events.title: August 15 : Assumption Day (national holiday)
events.description: This celebration, still very popular in Toulouse, is marked by several religious ceremonies.

events.title: Third weekend in September : European Heritage Days (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: The aim of the European Heritage Days is to open up numerous sites and monuments, many of which are normally closed to the public, such as castles and private collections. A great opportunity for a lovely stroll through the city to admire architectural treasures!

events.title: November 11: Remembrance Day (national holiday)
events.description: On this day, French citizens gather at war memorials to commemorate the signing of the 1918 Armistice officially bringing an end to the First World War.

events.title: November-December: Christmas Market (local event)
events.description: A traditional Christmas market is held in the Place du Capitole. Its welcoming log chalets all offer original gift ideas. An event not to be missed!

events.title: December 31:New Year's Eve (national event)
events.description: On the night of December 31<sup>st</sup>, the atmosphere is particularly festive on the streets of Bordeaux, with families and friends celebrating the new year.

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: Government Offices
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 12 p.m. and 1 p.m. to 4:30 p.m.

banks.title: Banks
banks.openingHours: Tuesday to Friday from 08:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and 1:30 p.m. to 5 p.m. (open until 12:30 p.m. on Saturdays)

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime:
Start of daylight saving time: last Sunday in March

End of daylight saving time: last Sunday in October
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Toulouse like elsewhere in France, a service charge is always included in the bill. If you are particularly pleased with the service, you may certainly leave a few extra euros on the table. But this additional tip is neither expected nor necessary.
